column4: yeah.. glade is in the repos, just search for glade-gnome with Synaptic
but we are discussing java-gnome
i use glade to layout my gui's with java-gnome
i use glade for java as well.
quite frankly it is the best gui layer-outter there is ;)
best one I've used, atleast
well i have used a couple other ones and glade wins
they are all frontends to cdrecord.
why not pull up a man page and just use cdrecord CLI
why waste time tracking down cdrecord's 130 fixme switches when I could just boot into windows and use nero
for starters i don't dual boot.  linux is it.  and has been for over 6yrs.
great scots.. it's been 8 years here started with redhat 4.2, kiddo
well i am sorry that you dual boot then .
still.

the problem with cdrecord is that it isn't really a piece of application software, it's more a frontend's engine anyway... since the developer made no effort at all to make any choices for the user, but just mirrored the available options provided by the ioctl interface of the drivers and just pile on the options.. no man should ever have to get that intimate with his cdrw/dvdr recorder just to backup some data
how hard is this: cdrecord dev=ATAPI:/dev/hdc foo.iso
not too hard, but that wouldn't work very well on my system.. plus, I'd have to mkisofs
I'll grant you, growisofs is allright in my book
and yes I realize it is a frontend for cdcrecord
eh.  if you like the one, then you could like them both.
all right.  lets just agree to disagree then.  this is sorta silly.
